content.content: Doo_StableLab:  Maybe we have different view points on it. And it’s not the first time he has been very incoherent in public as he shared, high on substances. Of course, we can discuss whether such is professional or not, but I can believe that it is not a professional conduct while you can believe that such statements with being high on substances and incoherent sentences is indeed professional.   Doo, I am a big believer in professionalism, accountability, and integrity. That being said, it probably makes the most sense to avoid shaming others. If we want to have a debate about a particular individual, let’s come with objective data and acknowledge the sensitivity of the issue. If we are going to have a broad discussion on professional expectations (presentation, accountability, transparency) that should happen without specific references to named individuals. That being said, we do need a facilitator code of conduct with expectations around professional/personal interactions and the relationships between IC and Facilitators. Codifying these expectations is important. As we saw with the recent “informal” meetings, there are currently mismatched expectations that are creating conflict and confusion. At present, we have an opportunity to address these challenges in a meaningful way, without finger pointing. Let’s take it…

content.content: That’s an interesting point. As the community is aware, there’s code of conduct for Recognized Delegate, focusing on integrity and conflict of interest. But it’s more of social encouragement. There can be something similar for facilitators but I think the difference is if Delegates act in bad faith or violate codes, they are in theory punished by Delegators pulling their votes. For facilitators, it would be either pressure to change the facilitator or budget adjustments. But that’s ultimately up to MKR voters

content.content: I’m a huge fan of consistent, honest and informative communication @Doo_StableLab  (professional is a buzzword IMHO)  as it builds trust inside and outside. But I’m also against shaming in public as it is pointless and plain harmful to everyone and everything involved. My course of action if I had negative feelings about somebody else’s behaviours would be:   Reach out and ask to help - it’s amazing what people can discover when they actually reach out and offer help   If that doesn’t work, discuss with someone I trust (perhaps they don’t share my negativity? - as is clearly the case here as well). If we agree,  then reach out to the person together (still trying to be a human being first, but also being honest about our feared potential implications of that person’s behaviour)   At this point, usually things solve themselves.  Shit happens to people, times are rough and this is the world where communities such as ours get a litmus test done. And btw. Scientific Governance does not exist without Humane Humans
